Enhancing Privacy in Federated Learning
through Local Training

Nicola Bastianello, Changxin Liu, Karl H. Johansson The authors are with the School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, and Digital Futures, KTH Royal Institute of Technology, Sweden. { nicolba | changxin | kallej }@kth.se.This work was partially supported by the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under grant agreement No. 101070162, partially by the Swedish Research Council Distinguished Professor Grant 2017-01078, Knut and Alice Wallenberg Foundation Wallenberg Scholar Grant, and partially by the NSERC Postdoctoral Fellowship PDF-577876-2023.
Abstract

In this paper we propose the federated private local training algorithm (Fed-PLT) for federated learning, to overcome the challenges of (i) expensive communications and (ii) privacy preservation. We address (i) by allowing for both partial participation and local training, which significantly reduce the number of communication rounds between the central coordinator and computing agents. The algorithm matches the state of the art in the sense that the use of local training demonstrably does not impact accuracy. Additionally, agents have the flexibility to choose from various local training solvers, such as (stochastic) gradient descent and accelerated gradient descent. Further, we investigate how employing local training can enhance privacy, addressing point (ii). In particular, we derive differential privacy bounds and highlight their dependence on the number of local training epochs. We assess the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm by comparing it to alternative techniques, considering both theoretical analysis and numerical results from a classification task.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, privacy, local training, partial participation

I Introduction

Federated learning has proved to be a powerful framework to enable private cooperative learning [1, 2, 3]. Indeed, federated learning allows a set of agents to pool their resources together to train a more accurate model than any single agent could. This is accomplished by relying on a central coordinator that iteratively collects and aggregates locally trained models – without the need to share raw data. Federated learning has been successfully deployed in different applications, including healthcare [4], wireless networks [5], mobile devices, Internet-of-Things, and sensor networks [6], power systems [7], and intelligent transportation [8], to name a few.

Clearly, all these applications may involve potentially sensitive and/or proprietary training data. Therefore, a fundamental challenge in the federated set-up is to guarantee the privacy of these data throughout the learning process. However, despite the fact that in a federated architecture the agents are not required to share raw data, various attacks have emerged to extract private information from the trained model or its predictions [9, 10, 11]. Thus, employing the federated learning architecture is not sufficient to ensure privacy, and tailored techniques need to be developed [12].

Besides privacy preservation, another fundamental challenge in federated learning is the expensiveness of communications. Indeed, the models exchanged by the agents are oftentimes high dimensional, especially when training (deep) neural networks [3], resulting in resource-intensive communications. Thus, one of the most important objectives is to design federated learning algorithms that employ as few communications as possible, while still guaranteeing good accuracy of the trained model. Different heuristics have been proposed to accomplish this objective, with the main ones arguably being partial participation111A.k.a. client selection. [13], local training [14], and quantization/compression [15]. In this paper we will focus on the former two, which we review in the following.

As the name suggests, when applying partial participation only a subset of the agents is selected at each iteration to communicate their local models to the coordinator. This allows to reduce the number of agent-coordinator communications required, at the cost of potentially slower convergence [13]. Local training proposes a complementary approach, by aiming to increase the time between communication rounds. The idea is for the agents to perform multiple epochs of local training (e.g. via stochastic gradient descent) for each round of communication. However, this may result in worse accuracy, especially due to the client drift phenomenon [14]. Indeed, locally trained models may be biased by the use of data that are not representative of the overall distribution, thus leading to a drift that cannot be corrected by the coordinator. In this paper we will therefore focus on designing a federated learning algorithm that allows for both partial participation and local training – without compromising accuracy.

Summarizing the discussion above, the objective of this paper is two-fold. On the one hand, we are interested in designing a privacy-preserving federated learning algorithm. On the other hand, we require that such algorithm employs partial participation and local training to reduce the number of communications, but without affecting accuracy. The approach we propose to pursue these objectives is to leverage local training to enhance privacy, highlighting the synergy of communication reduction and privacy. In particular, we offer the following contributions:

  1. 1.

    We design a federated learning algorithm, abbreviated as Fed-PLT, based on the Peaceman-Rachford splitting method [16], which allows for both partial participation and local training. In particular, the algorithm allows for a subset of the agents to activate randomly at each iteration, and communicate the results of local training to the coordinator. The number of local training epochs is a tunable parameter of the algorithm. Moreover, the algorithm can be applied to both smooth and composite problems (with a smooth and non-smooth part).

  2. 2.

    We prove exact convergence (in mean) of Fed-PLT in strongly convex, composite scenarios when the agents use gradient descent during local training. This results shows that the use of local training does not give rise to the client drift phenomenon, and thus it does not degrade accuracy of the trained model. Additionally, we analyze Fed-PLT’s convergence when the agents employ accelerated gradient descent for local training, showing the flexibility of the proposed approach.

  3. 3.

    We further analyze the convergence of Fed-PLT when stochastic gradient descent or noisy gradient descent are used for local training. The result characterizes convergence to a neighborhood of the optimal solution which depends on the variance of the noise. We then highlight the privacy benefits of using local training with a noisy solver. In particular, we characterize the differential privacy of the disclosed final model, as a function of the number of local training epochs and the gradient noise.

  4. 4.

    We apply Fed-PLT for a logistic regression problem, and compare its performance with a number of state-of-the-art federated algorithm that employ local training. We observe that the convergence rate of the proposed algorithm, in this example, is smaller than all other alternatives. We then analyze Fed-PLT by discussing its performance for different values of the tunable parameters and number of agents. One interesting observation is that the convergence rate is not a monotonically decreasing function of the number of local epochs (as may be suggested by Fed-PLT’s foundation in the Peaceman-Rachford splitting). Rather, there exists an optimal, finite number of epochs.

I-A Related works

(Private) federated learning is an active and growing area of research, and providing a comprehensive overview of the literature is outside the scope of this paper. In the following, we provide a brief overview of privacy in federated learning, and discuss the state of the art in federated algorithms employing local training.

Different privacy techniques have been proposed, with the most studied being homomorphic encryption [17], secret-sharing protocol [18], and differential privacy (DP) [19]. The latter stands out as easier to implement as compared to the other two methodologies. This is indeed the case as in differential privacy the aim is to obscure local training data by introducing perturbations to the models shared by the agents. This is achieved by simply randomizing learning algorithms with additive noise (often following a normal or Laplace distribution). But despite the simplicity of such privacy mechanism, DP provides a solid framework that enables the derivation of theoretical privacy guarantees [20, 21]. We remark that recently, the use of random additive noise to improve privacy has also been complemented with other techniques such as quantization and compression of communications [22, 23, 24]. This is similar to the concept of employing local training to enhance privacy, as explored in this paper. Owing to its effectiveness, differential privacy has been fruitfully applied in diverse engineering fields, ranging from federated learning [3] and distributed optimization [25], to control system design [26], estimation [27], and consensus-seeking [28]. Thus we will follow these works in using DP throughout this paper.

We turn now to reviewing related works on federated learning with local training. In particular, we consider Fed-PD [29], FedLin [30], TAMUNA [31], LED [32], 5GCS [14]. Their comparison with the proposed Fed-PLT is summarized in Table I.

Let us start by evaluating the memory footprint of the different algorithms. In Table I we report the number of models that need to be stored by agents and coordinator in between communication rounds. As we can see, except for [14], all other methods – including Fed-PLT– require the storage of 2​N+12𝑁12N+1 variables, i.e. two models per agent and one at the coordinator.

Turning now to the local training, we can classify algorithms based on the solvers that can be applied by the agents. For [29, 30, 31, 32] only (stochastic) gradient descent is allowed, while Fed-PLT also allows for accelerated (S)GD and noisy GD (to enhance privacy). Only [14] potentially allows for a broader class of solvers, provided that they verify a specific descent inequality. Such inequality is verified by SGD and variance reduced SGD, but [14] does not evaluate if accelerated SGD verifies it. The compared algorithms also differ in the number of local training epochs that the agents can perform. On one side, we have [31] which implements local training by randomly choosing whether to perform a communication round at each gradient step. On the other we have [29, 30, 32, 14] and Fed-PLT, which apply a deterministic number of local epochs Nesubscript𝑁e{N_{\mathrm{e}}}. However, for [29, 14] convergence is guaranteed only if Nesubscript𝑁e{N_{\mathrm{e}}} is lower bounded by N¯esubscript¯𝑁e\underaccent{\bar}{N}_{\mathrm{e}}, which may be larger than 111.

Partial participation is allowed only in the proposed Fed-PLT and [31, 14], and not in [29, 30, 32]. Furthermore, only Fed-PLT includes a privacy preserving mechanism with a rigorous differential privacy guarantee (derived in section VI). All the other methods do not evaluate the privacy perspective.

Finally, the algorithms also differ in the classes of problems for which a convergence guarantee can be derived. [29, 30, 32] present more general results for non-convex problems, while the assumption of strong convexity is required in the analysis of Fed-PLT and [31, 14]. However, Fed-PLT can be applied on composite problems, differently from all the other algorithms that are designed for smooth problems only.

II Preliminaries

II-A Operator theory

In the following we review some notions in operator theory 222Following the convention in the convex optimization literature, we use the term operator, even though in finite-dimensional spaces mapping would be more appropriate.; for a comprehensive background we refer to [16, 33]. The central goal in operator theory is to find the fixed points of a given operator.

Definition 1 (Fixed points).

Consider the operator 𝒯:ℝn→ℝn:𝒯→superscriptℝ𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛\mathcal{T}:\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}^{n}, we say that \mathbold​x¯∈ℝn¯\mathbold𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛\bar{\mathbold{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} is a fixed point of 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} if \mathbold​x¯=𝒯​\mathbold​x¯¯\mathbold𝑥𝒯¯\mathbold𝑥\bar{\mathbold{x}}=\mathcal{T}\bar{\mathbold{x}}.

The properties of an operator characterize its fixed points and dictate what techniques can be used to find them. An especially amenable class is that of contractive operators, defined below, for which the Banach-Picard theorem [16, Theorem 1.50], reported in Lemma 1, holds.

Definition 2 (Contractive operators).

The operator 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is ζ𝜁\zeta-contractive, ζ∈(0,1)𝜁01\zeta\in(0,1), if:

∥𝒯​\mathbold​x−𝒯​\mathbold​y∥≤ζ​∥\mathbold​x−\mathbold​y∥,∀\mathbold​x,\mathbold​y∈ℝn.formulae-sequencedelimited-∥∥𝒯\mathbold𝑥𝒯\mathbold𝑦𝜁delimited-∥∥\mathbold𝑥\mathbold𝑦for-all\mathbold𝑥\mathbold𝑦superscriptℝ𝑛\left\lVert\mathcal{T}\mathbold{x}-\mathcal{T}\mathbold{y}\right\rVert\leq\zeta\left\lVert\mathbold{x}-\mathbold{y}\right\rVert,\quad\forall\mathbold{x},\mathbold{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. (1)
Lemma 1 (Banach-Picard).

Let 𝒯:ℝn→ℝn:𝒯→superscriptℝ𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛\mathcal{T}:\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}^{n} be ζ𝜁\zeta-contractive; then 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} has a unique fixed point \mathbold​x¯¯\mathbold𝑥\bar{\mathbold{x}}, which is the limit of the sequence generated by:

\mathbold​xℓ+1=𝒯​\mathbold​xℓ,ℓ∈ℕ,\mathbold​x0∈ℝn.formulae-sequence\mathboldsuperscript𝑥ℓ1𝒯\mathboldsuperscript𝑥ℓformulae-sequenceℓℕ\mathboldsuperscript𝑥0superscriptℝ𝑛\mathbold{x}^{\ell+1}=\mathcal{T}\mathbold{x}^{\ell},\quad\ell\in\mathbb{N},\ \mathbold{x}^{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. (2)

In particular, it holds ∥\mathbold​xℓ−\mathbold​x¯∥≤ζℓ​∥\mathbold​x0−\mathbold​x¯∥.delimited-∥∥\mathboldsuperscript𝑥ℓ¯\mathbold𝑥superscript𝜁ℓdelimited-∥∥\mathboldsuperscript𝑥0¯\mathbold𝑥\left\lVert\mathbold{x}^{\ell}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert\leq\zeta^{\ell}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}^{0}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert.

II-B Application to convex optimization

Operator theory can be applied to solve convex optimization problems by reformulating them into fixed point problems. In the following we review two operator-based solvers that will be useful throughout the paper.

Lemma 2 (Gradient descent).

Let f∈ℱλ¯,λ¯​(ℝn)𝑓subscriptℱ¯𝜆¯𝜆superscriptℝ𝑛f\in\mathcal{F}_{{\underline{\lambda}},{\bar{\lambda}}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right), then the gradient descent operator

𝒯=ℐ−ρ​∇f​(⋅)𝒯ℐ𝜌∇𝑓⋅\mathcal{T}=\mathcal{I}-\rho\nabla f(\cdot)

with ρ∈(0,2/λ¯)𝜌02¯𝜆\rho\in(0,2/{\bar{\lambda}}) is ζ𝜁\zeta-contractive, ζ=max⁡{|1−ρ​λ¯|,|1−ρ​λ¯|}𝜁1𝜌¯𝜆1𝜌¯𝜆\zeta=\max\{|1-\rho{\underline{\lambda}}|,|1-\rho{\bar{\lambda}}|\} [33, p. 15], and the unique fixed point of 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} coincides with the minimizer of f𝑓f.

Clearly, the gradient descent algorithm can be applied to solve the smooth problem min\mathbold⁡x​f​(\mathbold​x)subscript\mathbold𝑥𝑓\mathbold𝑥\min_{\mathbold}{x}f(\mathbold{x}). To solve the composite problem min\mathbold⁡x​f​(\mathbold​x)+g​(\mathbold​x)subscript\mathbold𝑥𝑓\mathbold𝑥𝑔\mathbold𝑥\min_{\mathbold}{x}f(\mathbold{x})+g(\mathbold{x}), with f𝑓f smooth and g𝑔g non-smooth, we need to resort to different algorithms, such as the Peaceman-Rachford splitting (PRS) of Lemma 3. To introduce the PRS we first need to define the proximal and reflective operators.

Definition 3 (Proximal, reflective operators).

Let f∈ℱ0,∞​(ℝn)𝑓subscriptℱ0superscriptℝ𝑛f\in\mathcal{F}_{0,\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) and ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0, then the proximal operator of f𝑓f at \mathbold​y∈ℝn\mathbold𝑦superscriptℝ𝑛\mathbold{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} with penalty ρ𝜌\rho is defined as

proxρ​f⁡(\mathbold​y)=arg​min\mathbold​x∈ℝn⁡{f​(\mathbold​x)+12​ρ​∥\mathbold​x−\mathbold​y∥2}.subscriptprox𝜌𝑓\mathbold𝑦subscriptargmin\mathbold𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛𝑓\mathbold𝑥12𝜌superscriptdelimited-∥∥\mathbold𝑥\mathbold𝑦2\operatorname{prox}_{\rho f}(\mathbold{y})=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\mathbold{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}\left\{f(\mathbold{x})+\frac{1}{2\rho}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}-\mathbold{y}\right\rVert^{2}\right\}.

The reflective operator of f𝑓f at \mathbold​y∈ℝn\mathbold𝑦superscriptℝ𝑛\mathbold{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} is then defined as reflρ​f⁡(\mathbold​y)=2​proxρ​f⁡(\mathbold​y)−\mathbold​y.subscriptrefl𝜌𝑓\mathbold𝑦2subscriptprox𝜌𝑓\mathbold𝑦\mathbold𝑦\operatorname{refl}_{\rho f}(\mathbold{y})=2\operatorname{prox}_{\rho f}(\mathbold{y})-\mathbold{y}.

Notice that by definition, the proximal of a convex function f𝑓f is unique, as it is the minimizer of a strongly convex problem. Moreover, if f𝑓f is the indicator function of a convex set ℂℂ\mathbb{C}, then its proximal coincides with the projection onto the set, denoted by projℂsubscriptprojℂ\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbb{C}}. In the following we call a function f𝑓f proximable if its proximal (and hence reflective) can be computed in closed form or in a computationally inexpensive way, see [34] for some examples.

We are now ready to introduce the PRS.

Lemma 3 (Peaceman-Rachford splitting).

Consider the optimization problem \mathbold​x¯=arg​min\mathbold⁡x​f​(\mathbold​x)+g​(\mathbold​x)¯\mathbold𝑥subscriptargmin\mathbold𝑥𝑓\mathbold𝑥𝑔\mathbold𝑥\bar{\mathbold{x}}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\mathbold}{x}f(\mathbold{x})+g(\mathbold{x}) with f∈ℱλ¯,λ¯​(ℝn)𝑓subscriptℱ¯𝜆¯𝜆superscriptℝ𝑛f\in\mathcal{F}_{{\underline{\lambda}},{\bar{\lambda}}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) and g∈ℱ0,∞​(ℝn)𝑔subscriptℱ0superscriptℝ𝑛g\in\mathcal{F}_{0,\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right). 𝒯=reflρ​f∘reflρ​g𝒯subscriptrefl𝜌𝑓subscriptrefl𝜌𝑔\mathcal{T}=\operatorname{refl}_{\rho f}\circ\operatorname{refl}_{\rho g}

for ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0. The operator 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is ζ𝜁\zeta-contractive [35, Theorem 2], with

ζ=max⁡{|1−ρ​λ¯1+ρ​λ¯|,|1−ρ​λ¯1+ρ​λ¯|},𝜁1𝜌¯𝜆1𝜌¯𝜆1𝜌¯𝜆1𝜌¯𝜆\zeta=\max\left\{\left|\frac{1-\rho{\bar{\lambda}}}{1+\rho{\bar{\lambda}}}\right|,\left|\frac{1-\rho{\underline{\lambda}}}{1+\rho{\underline{\lambda}}}\right|\right\},

and its unique fixed point \mathbold​z¯¯\mathbold𝑧\bar{\mathbold{z}} is such that \mathbold​x¯=proxρ​g⁡(\mathbold​z¯)=proxρ​f⁡(2​\mathbold​x¯−\mathbold​z¯)¯\mathbold𝑥subscriptprox𝜌𝑔¯\mathbold𝑧subscriptprox𝜌𝑓2¯\mathbold𝑥¯\mathbold𝑧\bar{\mathbold{x}}=\operatorname{prox}_{\rho g}(\bar{\mathbold{z}})=\operatorname{prox}_{\rho f}(2\bar{\mathbold{x}}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}).

Applying the Banach-Picard iteration eq. 2 to the PRS operator defined in Lemma 3 yields the updates [35, section 3]

II-C Stochastic operator theory

In many learning applications the methods described in the previous section II-B cannot be directly applied due to practical constraints. For example, the gradient descent of Lemma 2 may only have access to stochastic gradients [36]. And, in decentralized set-ups, asynchronous computations may result in only some of the components of \mathbold​x\mathbold𝑥\mathbold{x} being updated at any given time [37]. In these scenarios, optimization algorithms are modeled by stochastic operators, which we briefly review in this section, see [38] and references therein.

Consider the operator 𝒯:ℝn​N→ℝn​N:𝒯→superscriptℝ𝑛𝑁superscriptℝ𝑛𝑁\mathcal{T}:\mathbb{R}^{nN}\to\mathbb{R}^{nN} that maps \mathbold​x=[x1⊤,…,xN⊤]⊤\mathbold𝑥superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑥1top…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑁toptop\mathbold{x}=[x_{1}^{\top},\ldots,x_{N}^{\top}]^{\top}, xi∈ℝnsubscript𝑥𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛x_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}, into 𝒯​\mathbold​x=[(𝒯1​\mathbold​x)⊤,…,(𝒯N​\mathbold​x)⊤]⊤𝒯\mathbold𝑥superscriptlimit-fromsubscript𝒯1\mathbold𝑥top…superscriptsubscript𝒯𝑁\mathbold𝑥toptop\mathcal{T}\mathbold{x}=[(\mathcal{T}_{1}\mathbold{x})\top,\ldots,(\mathcal{T}_{N}\mathbold{x})^{\top}]^{\top}. We define the stochastic Banach-Picard for 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} as the update

xi,k+1={𝒯i​\mathbold​xk+ei,kif​ui,k=1xi,kotherwisesubscript𝑥𝑖𝑘1casessubscript𝒯𝑖\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑒𝑖𝑘ifsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1subscript𝑥𝑖𝑘otherwisex_{i,k+1}=\begin{cases}\mathcal{T}_{i}\mathbold{x}_{k}+e_{i,k}&\text{if}\ u_{i,k}=1\\ x_{i,k}&\text{otherwise}\end{cases} (4)

where ui,k∼B​e​r​(pi)similar-tosubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘𝐵𝑒𝑟subscript𝑝𝑖u_{i,k}\sim Ber(p_{i}), pi∈(0,1]subscript𝑝𝑖01p_{i}\in(0,1], models randomized coordinate updates, and the random vector ei,ksubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘e_{i,k} models additive errors due e.g. to the use of stochastic gradients. We will denote \mathbold​ek=[e1,k⊤,…,eN,k⊤]⊤\mathboldsubscript𝑒𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒1𝑘top…superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑁𝑘toptop\mathbold{e}_{k}=[e_{1,k}^{\top},\ldots,e_{N,k}^{\top}]^{\top}. The following result can be derived as a stochastic version of Lemma 1, see [38, Proposition 1].

Lemma 4 (Stochastic Banach-Picard).

Assume that 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} in eq. 4 is ζ𝜁\zeta-contractive with fixed point \mathbold​x¯¯\mathbold𝑥\bar{\mathbold{x}}. Assume that {ui,k}k∈ℕsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘𝑘ℕ\{u_{i,k}\}_{k\in\mathbb{N}} and {ei,k}k∈ℕsubscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘𝑘ℕ\{e_{i,k}\}_{k\in\mathbb{N}} are i.i.d. and independent of each other, and 𝔼​[∥\mathbold​ek∥]=ν<∞𝔼delimited-[]delimited-∥∥\mathboldsubscript𝑒𝑘𝜈\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\mathbold{e}_{k}\right\rVert\right]=\nu<\infty. Then the random sequence {\mathbold​xk}k∈ℕsubscript\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑘ℕ\{\mathbold{x}_{k}\}_{k\in\mathbb{N}} generated by eq. 4 with initial condition \mathbold​x0\mathboldsubscript𝑥0\mathbold{x}_{0} satisfies the following bound

𝔼​[∥\mathbold​xk−\mathbold​x¯∥]≤p¯p¯​(ζ¯k​∥\mathbold​x0−\mathbold​x¯∥+1−ζ¯k1−ζ¯​ν)𝔼delimited-[]delimited-∥∥\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘¯\mathbold𝑥¯𝑝¯𝑝superscript¯𝜁𝑘delimited-∥∥\mathboldsubscript𝑥0¯\mathbold𝑥1superscript¯𝜁𝑘1¯𝜁𝜈\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert\right]\leq\sqrt{\frac{\bar{p}}{\underaccent{\bar}{p}}}\left(\bar{\zeta}^{k}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{0}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert+\frac{1-\bar{\zeta}^{k}}{1-\bar{\zeta}}\nu\right)

where p¯=mini⁡pi¯𝑝subscript𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖\underaccent{\bar}{p}=\min_{i}p_{i}, p¯=maxi⁡pi¯𝑝subscript𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖\bar{p}=\max_{i}p_{i}, and ζ¯=1−p¯+p¯​ζ2¯𝜁1¯𝑝¯𝑝superscript𝜁2\bar{\zeta}=\sqrt{1-\underaccent{\bar}{p}+\underaccent{\bar}{p}\zeta^{2}}.

II-D Differential privacy

In this section we review some concepts in differential privacy. Let 𝒟={ξ1,…,ξq}𝒟superscript𝜉1…superscript𝜉𝑞\mathcal{D}=\{\xi^{1},\dots,\xi^{q}\} denote a dataset of size q𝑞q with records drawn from a universe 𝕏𝕏\mathbb{X}. Two datasets 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime} are referred to as neighboring if they are of the same size and differ in at most one data point.

Definition 4 (Rényi differential privacy).

Given λ>1𝜆1\lambda>1, a randomized mechanism ℳ:𝕏q→𝕐:ℳ→superscript𝕏𝑞𝕐\mathcal{M}:\mathbb{X}^{q}\rightarrow\mathbb{Y} is said to have (λ,ε)𝜆𝜀(\lambda,\varepsilon)-Rényi differential privacy (RDP) [39], if for every pair of neighboring datasets 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, 𝒟′∈𝕏qsuperscript𝒟′superscript𝕏𝑞\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{X}^{q}, we have

Dλ(ℳ(𝒟)||ℳ(𝒟′))≤ε,{\rm D}_{\lambda}(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})||\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))\leq\varepsilon,

where Dλ(ℳ(𝒟)||ℳ(𝒟′)){\rm D}_{\lambda}(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})||\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})) is the λ𝜆\lambda-Rényi divergence between ℳ​(𝒟)ℳ𝒟\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}) and ℳ​(𝒟′)ℳsuperscript𝒟′\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}), i.e.,

Dλ(ℳ(𝒟)||ℳ(𝒟′))=1λ−1​log​∫𝕐ℙ​[ℳ​(𝒟)=z]λ​ℙ​[ℳ​(𝒟′)=z]1−λ​𝑑z.\begin{split}&{\rm D}_{\lambda}(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})||\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))\\ &=\frac{1}{\lambda-1}\log\int_{\mathbb{Y}}\mathbb{P}[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})=z]^{\lambda}\mathbb{P}[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})=z]^{1-\lambda}dz.\end{split}

Another common notion in differential privacy is approximate differential privacy (ADP) [19]. In the following we introduce its definition and how RDP can be translated into ADP [39].

Definition 5 (Approximate differential privacy).

Given ε,δ≥0𝜀𝛿0\varepsilon,\delta\geq 0, a randomized mechanism ℳ:𝕏q→𝕐:ℳ→superscript𝕏𝑞𝕐\mathcal{M}:\mathbb{X}^{q}\rightarrow\mathbb{Y} is said to be (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-ADP, if for every pair of neighboring datasets 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, 𝒟′∈𝕏qsuperscript𝒟′superscript𝕏𝑞\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{X}^{q} and every subset 𝒪⊆𝕐𝒪𝕐\mathcal{O}\subseteq\mathbb{Y}, we have

ℙ​[ℳ​(𝒟)∈𝒪]≤eε​ℙ​[ℳ​(𝒟′)∈𝒪]+δ.ℙdelimited-[]ℳ𝒟𝒪superscript𝑒𝜀ℙdelimited-[]ℳsuperscript𝒟′𝒪𝛿\begin{split}\mathbb{P}[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})\in\mathcal{O}]\leq e^{\varepsilon}\mathbb{P}[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D^{\prime}})\in\mathcal{O}]+\delta.\end{split}
Lemma 5 (RDP to ADP conversion).

If a randomized algorithm is (λ,ε𝜆𝜀\lambda,\varepsilon)-RDP, then it is (ε+log⁡(1/δ)λ−1,δ)𝜀1𝛿𝜆1𝛿(\varepsilon+\frac{\log(1/\delta)}{\lambda-1},\delta)-ADP, ∀δ∈(0,1)for-all𝛿01\forall\delta\in(0,1).

III Problem Formulation

In the following we formally describe the problem at hand, and discuss the application-driven design objectives that the proposed algorithm should satisfy.

III-A Problem

Consider the federated learning set-up stylized in Figure 1, in which N𝑁N agents and a coordinator cooperate towards the solution of the composite optimization problem

x¯=arg​minx∈ℝn​∑i=1Nfi​(x)+h​(x)¯𝑥subscriptargmin𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥ℎ𝑥\bar{x}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}\ \sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x)+h(x) (5)

where

fi​(x):=1q​∑j=1qℓi​(x;ξi(j))assignsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑥1𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑞subscriptℓ𝑖𝑥superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑗f_{i}(x):=\frac{1}{q}\sum_{j=1}^{q}\ell_{i}\left(x;\xi_{i}^{(j)}\right)

is the local cost function of agent i𝑖i characterized by a local dataset 𝒟i={ξi(1),…,ξi(q)}subscript𝒟𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖1…superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑞\mathcal{D}_{i}=\{\xi_{i}^{(1)},\dots,\xi_{i}^{(q)}\}, ℓi​(x,ξ)subscriptℓ𝑖𝑥𝜉\ell_{i}(x,\xi) is the loss of the machine learning model over the data instance ξ𝜉\xi, and h:ℝn→ℝ∪{+∞}:ℎ→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝh:\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}\cup\{+\infty\} is a common regularization function, which may be non-smooth. We introduce the following assumption.

Assumption 1.

The local loss functions ℓisubscriptℓ𝑖\ell_{i}, i∈{1,…,N}𝑖1…𝑁i\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, are λ¯¯𝜆{\underline{\lambda}}-strongly convex and λ¯¯𝜆{\bar{\lambda}}-smooth with respect to the first argument. The cost hℎh is convex, closed, and proper333A function h:ℝn→ℝ:ℎ→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝh:\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R} is closed if for any t∈ℝ𝑡ℝt\in\mathbb{R} the set {\mathbold​x∈ℝn|f​(\mathbold​x)≤t}conditional-set\mathbold𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛𝑓\mathbold𝑥𝑡\{\mathbold{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\ |\ f(\mathbold{x})\leq t\} is closed; it is proper if h​(x)>−∞ℎ𝑥h(x)>-\infty for any x∈ℝn𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}., and it is proximable.

We remark that Assumption 1 implies that each fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is both λ¯¯𝜆{\underline{\lambda}}-strongly convex and λ¯¯𝜆{\bar{\lambda}}-smooth. In order to solve the problem in a federated set-up, the first step is to reformulate it into the following

\mathbold​x¯=arg​min\mathbold​x∈ℝn​N​∑i=1Nfi​(xi)+h​(x1)s.t.​x1=…=xN¯\mathbold𝑥subscriptargmin\mathbold𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖ℎsubscript𝑥1s.t.subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑁\begin{split}\bar{\mathbold{x}}=&\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\mathbold{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{nN}}\ \sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i})+h(x_{1})\\ &\text{s.t.}\ x_{1}=\ldots=x_{N}\end{split} (6)

where xi∈ℝnsubscript𝑥𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛x_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} are local copies of x𝑥x, and \mathbold​x=[x1⊤,…,xN⊤]\mathbold𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑥1top…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑁top\mathbold{x}=[x_{1}^{\top},\ldots,x_{N}^{\top}]. The consensus constraint x1=…=xNsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑁x_{1}=\ldots=x_{N} guarantees the equivalence of eq. 6 with eq. 5, and implies that \mathbold​x¯=𝟏N⊗x¯¯\mathbold𝑥tensor-productsubscript1𝑁¯𝑥\bar{\mathbold{x}}=\boldsymbol{1}_{N}\otimes\bar{x}, where x¯¯𝑥\bar{x} is the unique optimal solution of eq. 5. We can now rewrite eq. 6 in the following form

\mathbold​x¯=arg​min\mathbold​x∈ℝn​N⁡f​(\mathbold​x)+g​(\mathbold​x)¯\mathbold𝑥subscriptargmin\mathbold𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛𝑁𝑓\mathbold𝑥𝑔\mathbold𝑥\bar{\mathbold{x}}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\mathbold{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{nN}}f(\mathbold{x})+g(\mathbold{x}) (7)

with f​(\mathbold​x)=∑i=1Nfi​(xi)𝑓\mathbold𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖f(\mathbold{x})=\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i}), and g​(\mathbold​x)=ιℂ​(\mathbold​x)+h​(x1),𝑔\mathbold𝑥subscript𝜄ℂ\mathbold𝑥ℎsubscript𝑥1g(\mathbold{x})=\iota_{\mathbb{C}}(\mathbold{x})+h(x_{1}), where we imposed the consensus constraints through the indicator function of the consensus subspace

ℂ={\mathbold​x=[x1⊤,…,xN⊤]∈ℝn​N|x1=…=xN}.ℂconditional-set\mathbold𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑥1top…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑁topsuperscriptℝ𝑛𝑁subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑁\mathbb{C}=\{\mathbold{x}=[x_{1}^{\top},\ldots,x_{N}^{\top}]\in\mathbb{R}^{nN}\ |\ x_{1}=\ldots=x_{N}\}.

In principle, eq. 7 could be now solved applying the Peaceman-Rachford splitting of eq. 3, but due to practical constraints (discussed in section III-B) this may not be possible. Instead, in section IV we will show how to use PRS as a template to design a federated algorithm that can be applied in practice.

III-B Design objectives

In this section we discuss some of the challenges that arise in federated learning set-ups, due to the practical constraints that they pose [1, 3]. The objective in the remainder of the paper then is to design and analyze an algorithm that can provably overcome these challenges.

Communication burden

In machine learning we are often faced with the task of training high-dimensional models, with deep neural networks the foremost example. This implies that problem eq. 5 may be characterized by n≫1much-greater-than𝑛1n\gg 1. In a federated set-up then, sharing models between the agents and the coordinator imposes a significant communication burden [15]. Initial approaches to federated learning444Corresponding to the 1stsuperscript1st1^{\text{st}}–3rdsuperscript3rd3^{\text{rd}} generations in the categorization of [14]. therefore introduced different techniques to reduce the number of communications required, such as local training [3]. Local training requires that, before a round of communications, each agent perform multiple steps (or epochs) of minimization of the local loss function. Employing local training, however, may result in worse accuracy, especially when the loss functions of the agents are heterogeneous. The objective then is to design federated algorithms that perform local training without jeopardizing accuracy of the trained model, see e.g. [29, 30, 31, 14, 32].

Heterogeneous agents

The devices involved in the federated learning process may be in general very heterogeneous as regards to computational, storage, and communication capabilities. Indeed, these devices may be equipped with very different hardware (CPU, memory, battery), and they may be using different network connectivity (mobile or Wi-Fi) [1, 3]. The heterogeneity of the agents’ resources implies that they may perform local computations, and transmit their results, at different rates. This results in partial participation, with only a subset of the agents being active at any given time. Besides arising from practical limitations, partial participation may also be enforced in order to relieve the communication burden. The goal therefore is to design a federated algorithm that allows for partial participation while preserving accuracy of the trained model.

Privacy

The leakage of private information through machine learning models’ parameters and predictions has been extensively documented [9, 10, 11]. One notable example is the support vector machine (SVM) in its dual form, where the solution involves a linear combination of specific data points. Recently, there has been a growing interest in iterative randomized training algorithms that offer privacy-preserving guarantees [20, 21], such as RDP and ADP. However, the existing results suffer from privacy loss that increases over training epochs [40] and fail to support local training and the partial participation of heterogeneous agents [20]. These limitations make it challenging to extend those approaches to the specific setup addressed in this work. The objective of this study is to address these challenges by providing a rigorous privacy-preserving guarantee that remains bounded over time and is compatible with the federated learning setup under consideration.

To summarize, the goal of this paper is to design a federated algorithm with the following features:

  1. (i)

    Local training: the algorithm should allow for multiple epochs of local training, but without jeopardizing accuracy of the computed solution.

  2. (ii)

    Partial participation: the algorithm should allow for a subset of the agents to be active at any time, again without jeopardizing accuracy.

  3. (iii)

    Privacy: the algorithm should incorporate a privacy mechanism to safeguard the local training data.

IV Algorithm Design

In this section we derive and discuss the proposed Algorithm 1, highlighting the different design choices that it allows for.

IV-A Algorithm derivation

We start by applying the PRS of eq. 3 to the federated optimization problem eq. 7, which yields

However, in general eq. 10 does not have a closed form solution, and the agents can only approximate the update via a finite number of local training epochs. 666Even if a closed form solution is in principle available, we may not be able to actually compute it due to the high dimensionality of the problem. For example, if fi​(x)=12​x⊤​Ai​x+⟨bi,x⟩subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥12superscript𝑥topsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑥subscript𝑏𝑖𝑥f_{i}(x)=\frac{1}{2}x^{\top}A_{i}x+\langle b_{i},x\rangle then proxρ​fi⁡(vi,k)=(In+ρ​Ai)−1​(vi,k−bi)subscriptprox𝜌subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑛𝜌subscript𝐴𝑖1subscript𝑣𝑖𝑘subscript𝑏𝑖\operatorname{prox}_{\rho f_{i}}(v_{i,k})=\left(I_{n}+\rho A_{i}\right)^{-1}(v_{i,k}-b_{i}), which requires inversion of an n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n matrix. Therefore if n≫1much-greater-than𝑛1n\gg 1, the matrix inversion may be computationally expensive and thus the closed form update may be unavailable in practice. As a first approach, each agent can apply Ne∈ℕsubscript𝑁eℕ{N_{\mathrm{e}}}\in\mathbb{N} steps of gradient descent (cf. Lemma 2) to approximate the local update:

wi,k0=xi,kwi,kℓ+1=wi,kℓ−γ​∇di,k​(wi,kℓ)ℓ=0,…,Ne−1xi,k+1=wi,kNeformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘0subscript𝑥𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓ1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓ𝛾∇subscript𝑑𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓformulae-sequenceℓ0…subscript𝑁e1subscript𝑥𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘subscript𝑁e\begin{split}w_{i,k}^{0}&=x_{i,k}\\ w_{i,k}^{\ell+1}&=w_{i,k}^{\ell}-\gamma\nabla d_{i,k}(w_{i,k}^{\ell})\quad\ell=0,\ldots,{N_{\mathrm{e}}}-1\\ x_{i,k+1}&=w_{i,k}^{N_{\mathrm{e}}}\end{split} (11)

where γ∈(0,2/(λ¯+1/ρ))𝛾02¯𝜆1𝜌\gamma\in(0,2/({\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho)), since di,k∈ℱλ¯+1/ρ,λ¯+1/ρ​(ℝn)subscript𝑑𝑖𝑘subscriptℱ¯𝜆1𝜌¯𝜆1𝜌superscriptℝ𝑛d_{i,k}\in\mathcal{F}_{{\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho,{\bar{\lambda}}+1/\rho}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right). More generally, one can apply any suitable local solver to compute eq. 10, as discussed in section IV-B. In particular, the choice of local solver can be leveraged to enhance privacy.

Finally, in the derivation above, each agent approximates its local proximal at each iteration k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}. However, this is not required, as Algorithm 1 allows for only a subset of active agents to share the results of their local training at iteration k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}; this feature is discussed in section IV-C.

To summarize, the proposed Algorithm 1 provides two flexible design choices in the following key aspects:

  1. 1.

    local training: during local training, any suitable solver can be employed by the agents, including privacy preserving methods (objectives (i) and (iii));

  2. 2.

    partial participation: the algorithm allows for a subset of the agents to be active at any given time k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N} (objective (ii)).

IV-B Local training methods

In principle, one may choose to use any suitable local solver to approximate the solution of minxi⁡di,k​(xi)=fi​(xi)+(1/2​ρ)​∥xi−vi,k∥2subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖𝑘subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖12𝜌superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖𝑘2\min_{x_{i}}d_{i,k}(x_{i})=f_{i}(x_{i})+(1/2\rho)\left\lVert x_{i}-v_{i,k}\right\rVert^{2}. This problem is especially amenable since it is strongly convex, with di,k∈ℱλ¯+1/ρ,λ¯+1/ρ​(ℝn)subscript𝑑𝑖𝑘subscriptℱ¯𝜆1𝜌¯𝜆1𝜌superscriptℝ𝑛d_{i,k}\in\mathcal{F}_{{\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho,{\bar{\lambda}}+1/\rho}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right). A first option is the gradient descent, already discussed in eq. 11. Notice that by Lemma 2 we know that the gradient descent is contractive with rate χ=max⁡{|1−γ​(λ¯+1/ρ)|,|1−γ​(λ¯+1/ρ)|}𝜒1𝛾¯𝜆1𝜌1𝛾¯𝜆1𝜌\chi=\max\{|1-\gamma({\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho)|,|1-\gamma({\bar{\lambda}}+1/\rho)|\}, which is minimized by choosing γ=2/(λ¯+λ¯+2/ρ)𝛾2¯𝜆¯𝜆2𝜌\gamma=2/({\bar{\lambda}}+{\underline{\lambda}}+2/\rho). In the following, we discuss some alternatives that address different design objectives.

Accelerated gradient descent

Improving the performance of local training can be achieved by using the accelerated gradient descent, see e.g. [41, Algorithm 14], characterized by

wi,k0=xi,k,ui0=wi,k0uiℓ+1=wi,kℓ−1λ¯​∇di,k​(wi,kℓ)ℓ=0,…,Ne−1wi,kℓ+1=uiℓ+1+λ¯−λ¯λ¯+λ¯​(uiℓ+1−uiℓ)xi,k+1=wi,kNe,formulae-sequenceformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘0subscript𝑥𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖0superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘0superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖ℓ1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓ1¯𝜆∇subscript𝑑𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓformulae-sequenceℓ0…subscript𝑁e1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓ1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖ℓ1¯𝜆¯𝜆¯𝜆¯𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖ℓ1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖ℓsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘subscript𝑁e\begin{split}w_{i,k}^{0}&=x_{i,k},\ u_{i}^{0}=w_{i,k}^{0}\\ u_{i}^{\ell+1}&=w_{i,k}^{\ell}-\frac{1}{{\bar{\lambda}}}\nabla d_{i,k}(w_{i,k}^{\ell})\quad\ell=0,\ldots,{N_{\mathrm{e}}}-1\\ w_{i,k}^{\ell+1}&=u_{i}^{\ell+1}+\frac{\sqrt{{\bar{\lambda}}}-\sqrt{{\underline{\lambda}}}}{\sqrt{{\bar{\lambda}}}+\sqrt{{\underline{\lambda}}}}(u_{i}^{\ell+1}-u_{i}^{\ell})\\ x_{i,k+1}&=w_{i,k}^{N_{\mathrm{e}}},\end{split} (12)

which employs constant step-sizes owing to the strong convexity of di,ksubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘d_{i,k}. Local solvers with even better performance can also be chosen, for example (quasi-)Newton methods.

Stochastic gradient descent

Both gradient descent and accelerated gradient descent rely on the use of full gradient evaluations, which may be too computationally expensive in learning applications. Therefore, the agents may resort to stochastic gradient descent (SGD) methods [36], which employ approximated gradients during the local training. Recalling that the local costs are defined as fi​(x):=1q​∑j=1qℓi​(x;ξi(j)),assignsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑥1𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑞subscriptℓ𝑖𝑥superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑗f_{i}(x):=\frac{1}{q}\sum_{j=1}^{q}\ell_{i}(x;\xi_{i}^{(j)}), SGD makes use of the following approximate gradient

∇^​fi​(x)=1q​∑j∈ℬ∇ℓi​(x;ξi(j))^∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥1𝑞subscript𝑗ℬ∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑥superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑗\hat{\nabla}f_{i}(x)=\frac{1}{q}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{B}}\nabla\ell_{i}(x;\xi_{i}^{(j)})

where ℬ⊂{1,…,q}ℬ1…𝑞\mathcal{B}\subset\{1,\ldots,q\} are the indices of a subset of data points chosen at random.

Private local training

The previous local solvers address performance concerns; however, when the design objective is privacy preservation, the agents should resort to the use of noisy gradient descent [20, 42]. In particular, the update of wi,kℓ+1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓ1w_{i,k}^{\ell+1} in eq. 11 is perturbed with Gaussian noise:

wi,kℓ+1=wi,kℓ−γ​∇di,k​(wi,kℓ)+ti,kℓti,kℓ∼2​γ​𝒩​(0,τ2​In)superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓ1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓ𝛾∇subscript𝑑𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑘ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑘ℓsimilar-to2𝛾𝒩0superscript𝜏2subscript𝐼𝑛\begin{split}w_{i,k}^{\ell+1}&=w_{i,k}^{\ell}-\gamma\nabla d_{i,k}(w_{i,k}^{\ell})+t_{i,k}^{\ell}\\ t_{i,k}^{\ell}&\sim\sqrt{2\gamma}\mathcal{N}(0,\tau^{2}{I}_{n})\end{split} (13)

where ℓ=0,…,Ne−1ℓ0…subscript𝑁e1\ell=0,\ldots,{N_{\mathrm{e}}}-1, and τ2>0superscript𝜏20\tau^{2}>0 is the noise variance. The addition of a stochastic additive noise in each iteration of eq. 13 allows us to establish rigorous differential privacy guarantees, which can be tuned by selecting the variance τ2superscript𝜏2\tau^{2}.

Remark 1 (Uncoordinated local solvers).

In this section we only discussed the case of “coordinated” local solvers777The terminology “coordinated” and “uncoordinated” is borrowed from distributed optimization literature, see e.g. [43]., that is, all agents use the same solver with the same parameters (e.g. gradient with common – or coordinated – step-size γ𝛾\gamma). The results of section V actually allow for uncoordinated solvers, with the agents either using different algorithms, or the same algorithm with different parameters. For example, if the local costs are such that fi∈ℱλ¯i,λ¯i​(ℝn)subscript𝑓𝑖subscriptℱsubscript¯𝜆𝑖subscript¯𝜆𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛f_{i}\in\mathcal{F}_{{\underline{\lambda}}_{i},{\bar{\lambda}}_{i}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right), then the local step-size can be tuned using the strong convexity and smoothness moduli of fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}, instead of the global moduli λ¯=mini⁡λ¯i¯𝜆subscript𝑖subscript¯𝜆𝑖{\underline{\lambda}}=\min_{i}{\underline{\lambda}}_{i}, λ¯=maxi⁡λ¯i¯𝜆subscript𝑖subscript¯𝜆𝑖{\bar{\lambda}}=\max_{i}{\bar{\lambda}}_{i}. This is especially useful because it means that the algorithm can adapt to the heterogeneity of the local costs.

IV-C Partial participation

As discussed in section III-B, there are different reasons why only a subset of the agents may participate at any given time k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}. On the one hand, the heterogeneity of the agents’ hardware (CPU, battery, connectivity, …) may result in different paces of local training. This means that not all agents will conclude their computations at the same time, and the coordinator will receive new results only from those that did. On the other hand, partial participation can be introduced by design in order to reduce the communication burden. In this case, the coordinator picks a (random) subset of the agents and requests that they send the new results of local training, thus reducing the number of communications exchanged. This scheme is often referred to as client selection [14].

The proposed Algorithm 1 allows for any partial participation, be it intrinsic (due to heterogeneity of the agents) or extrinsic (due to client selection). In particular, the only requirement, detailed in Assumption 2, is that at any given time an agent i𝑖i participates in the learning with a given fixed probability pi∈(0,1]subscript𝑝𝑖01p_{i}\in(0,1].

V Convergence Analysis

In this section we prove the convergence of Algorithm 1. We start by showing that the proposed algorithm can be interpreted as a contractive operator. Then, building on this result we characterize convergence for the different local training choices discussed in section IV-B.

V-A Contractiveness of Algorithm 1

The goal of this section is to show that Algorithm 1 can be characterized as a contractive operator, similarly to the PRS from which it was derived. First of all, we remark that yk+1subscript𝑦𝑘1y_{k+1} only depends on \mathbold​zk\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘\mathbold{z}_{k}, and hence we can represent Algorithm 1 in terms of \mathbold​x\mathbold𝑥\mathbold{x} and \mathbold​z\mathbold𝑧\mathbold{z} only. In particular, letting 𝒳:ℝn​N×ℝn​N→ℝn​N:(\mathbold​xk,\mathbold​zk)↦\mathbold​xk+1:𝒳→superscriptℝ𝑛𝑁superscriptℝ𝑛𝑁superscriptℝ𝑛𝑁:maps-to\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘1\mathcal{X}:\mathbb{R}^{nN}\times\mathbb{R}^{nN}\to\mathbb{R}^{nN}:(\mathbold{x}_{k},\mathbold{z}_{k})\mapsto\mathbold{x}_{k+1} be the map denoting the local updates, and assuming that all agents are active, we can write

[\mathbold​xk+1\mathbold​zk+1]=[𝒳​(\mathbold​xk,\mathbold​zk)\mathbold​zk+2​(\mathbold​xk+1−proxρ​g⁡(\mathbold​zk))]=𝒯​[\mathbold​xk\mathbold​zk]matrix\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘1\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘1matrix𝒳\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘2\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘1subscriptprox𝜌𝑔\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘𝒯matrix\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘\displaystyle\begin{bmatrix}\mathbold{x}_{k+1}\\ \mathbold{z}_{k+1}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}\mathcal{X}(\mathbold{x}_{k},\mathbold{z}_{k})\\ \mathbold{z}_{k}+2(\mathbold{x}_{k+1}-\operatorname{prox}_{\rho g}(\mathbold{z}_{k}))\end{bmatrix}=\mathcal{T}\begin{bmatrix}\mathbold{x}_{k}\\ \mathbold{z}_{k}\end{bmatrix}

The following Proposition 1 proves that 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is contractive for a suitable choice of local solver.

Proposition 1 (Algorithm 1 is contractive).

Let the local solvers be χNesuperscript𝜒subscript𝑁e\chi^{N_{\mathrm{e}}}-contractive in the first argument, that is

and let the PRS applied to eq. 6 be ζ𝜁\zeta-contractive (cf. Lemma 3) with fixed point \mathbold​z¯¯\mathbold𝑧\bar{\mathbold{z}}. Let the parameters ρ𝜌\rho and Nesubscript𝑁e{N_{\mathrm{e}}} be chosen such that the following matrix is stable:

where recall that \mathbold​x¯k+1subscript¯\mathbold𝑥𝑘1\bar{\mathbold{x}}_{k+1} denotes the exact local updates, and 𝒯PRsubscript𝒯PR\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{PR}} denotes the exact PRS.

Finally, putting eqs. 16 and 17 together yields

[∥\mathbold​xk+1−\mathbold​x¯∥∥\mathbold​zk+1−\mathbold​z¯∥]≤S​[∥\mathbold​xk−\mathbold​x¯∥∥\mathbold​zk−\mathbold​z¯∥]matrixdelimited-∥∥\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘1¯\mathbold𝑥delimited-∥∥\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘1¯\mathbold𝑧𝑆matrixdelimited-∥∥\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘¯\mathbold𝑥delimited-∥∥\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘¯\mathbold𝑧\begin{bmatrix}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert\\ \left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k+1}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert\end{bmatrix}\leq S\begin{bmatrix}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert\\ \left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert\end{bmatrix}

and taking the square norm on both sides

≤∥S∥2​(∥\mathbold​xk−\mathbold​x¯∥2+∥\mathbold​zk−\mathbold​z¯∥2).absentsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑆2superscriptdelimited-∥∥\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘¯\mathbold𝑥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘¯\mathbold𝑧2\displaystyle\qquad\leq\left\lVert S\right\rVert^{2}\left(\left\lVert\mathbold{x}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert^{2}+\left\lVert\mathbold{z}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\right\rVert^{2}\right).

Therefore by Definition 2 this proves that Algorithm 1 is indeed contractive. ∎

Remark 2 (The importance of initialization).

Initializing the local update computation eq. 11 with wi,k0=xi,ksuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘0subscript𝑥𝑖𝑘w_{i,k}^{0}=x_{i,k} is fundamental to guarantee contractiveness of Algorithm 1, and thus its convergence, as detailed in the following section V-B.

V-B Convergence results

Proposition 1 proved that Algorithm 1 can be modeled as a contractive operator when all the agents are active. This fact then would allow us to characterize the convergence of the algorithm by using Banach-Picard theorem (cf. Lemma 1). However, in this section we are interested in analyzing convergence with partial participation, that is, when only a (random) subset of agents is active at each time k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}. In addition to partial participation, we are interested in convergence when a further source of stochasticity is present: inexact local solvers. In section IV-B we have indeed discussed two local solvers that, either due to computational constraints or privacy concerns, introduce inexactness during training.

To account for both partial participation and inexact local training, we can write Algorithm 1 as the following stochastic update

[xi,k+1zi,k+1]={[𝒳i​(xi,k,\mathbold​zk)zi,k+2​(𝒳i​(xi,k,\mathbold​zk)−yk+1)]+ei,kif​ui,k=1[xi,kzi,k]if​ui,k=0matrixsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑘1subscript𝑧𝑖𝑘1casesmatrixsubscript𝒳𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝑘\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑧𝑖𝑘2subscript𝒳𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝑘\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘1subscript𝑒𝑖𝑘otherwiseifsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1otherwisematrixsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑘subscript𝑧𝑖𝑘ifsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘0otherwise\begin{bmatrix}x_{i,k+1}\\ z_{i,k+1}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{cases}\begin{bmatrix}\mathcal{X}_{i}(x_{i,k},\mathbold{z}_{k})\\ z_{i,k}+2(\mathcal{X}_{i}(x_{i,k},\mathbold{z}_{k})-y_{k+1})\end{bmatrix}+e_{i,k}\\ \hskip 142.26378pt\text{if}\ u_{i,k}=1\\ \begin{bmatrix}x_{i,k}\\ z_{i,k}\end{bmatrix}\hskip 113.81102pt\text{if}\ u_{i,k}=0\end{cases} (18)

where ui,k∼B​e​r​(pi)similar-tosubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘𝐵𝑒𝑟subscript𝑝𝑖u_{i,k}\sim Ber(p_{i}) is the r.v. which equals 111 when agent i𝑖i is active at time k𝑘k, 𝒳isubscript𝒳𝑖\mathcal{X}_{i} denotes the i𝑖i-th component of the local updates map 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, and ei,ksubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘e_{i,k} is a random additive noise modeling inexact local updates.

We can now formalize the stochastic set-up of eq. 18 as follows, which will then allow convergence analysis with the tools of section II-C.

Assumption 2 (Stochastic set-up).
  2. 1.

    The random variables {ui,k}k∈ℕsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘𝑘ℕ\{u_{i,k}\}_{k\in\mathbb{N}} are i.i.d. Bernoulli with mean pi∈(0,1]subscript𝑝𝑖01p_{i}\in(0,1], for any i=1,…,N𝑖1…𝑁i=1,\ldots,N.

  3. 2.

    Let \mathbold​ek=[e1,k⊤,…,eN,k⊤]⊤\mathboldsubscript𝑒𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒1𝑘top…superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑁𝑘toptop\mathbold{e}_{k}=[e_{1,k}^{\top},\ldots,e_{N,k}^{\top}]^{\top} be the random vector collecting all additive errors. We assume that {\mathbold​ek}k∈ℕsubscript\mathboldsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑘ℕ\{\mathbold{e}_{k}\}_{k\in\mathbb{N}} are i.i.d. and such that 𝔼​[∥\mathbold​ek∥]=ν<∞𝔼delimited-[]delimited-∥∥\mathboldsubscript𝑒𝑘𝜈\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\mathbold{e}_{k}\right\rVert\right]=\nu<\infty.

  4. 3.

    For every k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}, {ui,k}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘𝑖1𝑁\{u_{i,k}\}_{i=1}^{N} and \mathbold​ek\mathboldsubscript𝑒𝑘\mathbold{e}_{k} are independent.

We are now ready to prove convergence of Algorithm 1.

Proposition 2 (Convergence).

Let the parameters of Algorithm 1 be such that Proposition 1 holds, and let Assumption 2 be verified. Then the sequence {[\mathbold​xk⊤,\mathbold​zk⊤]⊤}k∈ℕsubscriptsuperscript\mathboldsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘top\mathboldsuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝑘toptop𝑘ℕ\{[\mathbold{x}_{k}^{\top},\mathbold{z}_{k}^{\top}]^{\top}\}_{k\in\mathbb{N}} generated by the algorithm satisfies the following bound

𝔼​[∥[\mathbold​xk−\mathbold​x¯\mathbold​zk−\mathbold​z¯]∥]≤p¯p¯​(σk​∥[\mathbold​x0−\mathbold​x¯\mathbold​z0−\mathbold​z¯]∥+1−σk1−σ​ν)𝔼delimited-[]delimited-∥∥matrix\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘¯\mathbold𝑥\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘¯\mathbold𝑧¯𝑝¯𝑝superscript𝜎𝑘delimited-∥∥matrix\mathboldsubscript𝑥0¯\mathbold𝑥\mathboldsubscript𝑧0¯\mathbold𝑧1superscript𝜎𝑘1𝜎𝜈\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\begin{bmatrix}\mathbold{x}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\\ \mathbold{z}_{k}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\end{bmatrix}\right\rVert\right]\leq\sqrt{\frac{\bar{p}}{\underaccent{\bar}{p}}}\left(\sigma^{k}\left\lVert\begin{bmatrix}\mathbold{x}_{0}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\\ \mathbold{z}_{0}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\end{bmatrix}\right\rVert+\frac{1-\sigma^{k}}{1-\sigma}\nu\right)

where p¯=mini⁡pi¯𝑝subscript𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖\underaccent{\bar}{p}=\min_{i}p_{i}, p¯=maxi⁡pi¯𝑝subscript𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖\bar{p}=\max_{i}p_{i}, and σ=1−p¯+p¯​∥S∥2𝜎1¯𝑝¯𝑝superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑆2\sigma=\sqrt{1-\underaccent{\bar}{p}+\underaccent{\bar}{p}\left\lVert S\right\rVert^{2}}.

Proof.

If Proposition 1 is verified, then the algorithm is contractive, and under Assumption 2 we can apply the stochastic Banach-Picard of Lemma 4. ∎

Proposition 2 proves that, for a suitable choice of parameters, Algorithm 1 converges when the agents apply (stochastic) gradient descent during local training. The following result shows that convergence is achieved also when the agents employ the accelerated gradient descent as a local solver.

Proposition 3 (Convergence with accelerated gradient).

Let the agents employ the accelerated gradient as local solver. Let the parameters ρ𝜌\rho and Nesubscript𝑁e{N_{\mathrm{e}}} be chosen such that the following matrix is stable:

S′=[χ​(Ne)1+χ​(Ne)λ¯+1/ρ2​χ​(Ne)ζ+2​χ​(Ne)λ¯+1/ρ]superscript𝑆′matrix𝜒subscript𝑁e1𝜒subscript𝑁e¯𝜆1𝜌2𝜒subscript𝑁e𝜁2𝜒subscript𝑁e¯𝜆1𝜌S^{\prime}=\begin{bmatrix}\chi({N_{\mathrm{e}}})&\frac{1+\chi({N_{\mathrm{e}}})}{{\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho}\\ 2\chi({N_{\mathrm{e}}})&\zeta+\frac{2\chi({N_{\mathrm{e}}})}{{\underline{\lambda}}+1/\rho}\end{bmatrix}

where

χ​(Ne):=(1+λ¯/λ¯)​(1−λ¯/λ¯)Ne.assign𝜒subscript𝑁e1¯𝜆¯𝜆superscript1¯𝜆¯𝜆subscript𝑁e\chi({N_{\mathrm{e}}}):=\left(1+{\bar{\lambda}}/{\underline{\lambda}}\right)\left(1-\sqrt{{\underline{\lambda}}/{\bar{\lambda}}}\right)^{N_{\mathrm{e}}}.

Then the operator 𝒯′:ℝn​N×ℝn​N→ℝn​N×ℝn​N:superscript𝒯′→superscriptℝ𝑛𝑁superscriptℝ𝑛𝑁superscriptℝ𝑛𝑁superscriptℝ𝑛𝑁\mathcal{T}^{\prime}:\mathbb{R}^{nN}\times\mathbb{R}^{nN}\to\mathbb{R}^{nN}\times\mathbb{R}^{nN} characterizing Algorithm 1 (with accelerated gradient) is contractive and, under Assumption 2, Proposition 2 holds.

Proof.

The contractiveness of Algorithm 1 with accelerated gradient as local solver follows along the lines of the proof of Proposition 1, with χNesuperscript𝜒subscript𝑁e\chi^{N_{\mathrm{e}}} being replaced by χ​(Ne)𝜒subscript𝑁e\chi({N_{\mathrm{e}}}). Indeed, by Lemma 7 in the Appendix the local update map 𝒳′superscript𝒳′\mathcal{X}^{\prime} verifies

∥𝒳​(\mathbold​x,\mathbold​zk)−𝒳​(\mathbold​y,\mathbold​zk)∥≤χ​(Ne)​∥\mathbold​x−\mathbold​y∥,∀\mathbold​x,\mathbold​y∈ℝn.formulae-sequencedelimited-∥∥𝒳\mathbold𝑥\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘𝒳\mathbold𝑦\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘𝜒subscript𝑁edelimited-∥∥\mathbold𝑥\mathbold𝑦for-all\mathbold𝑥\mathbold𝑦superscriptℝ𝑛\left\lVert\mathcal{X}(\mathbold{x},\mathbold{z}_{k})-\mathcal{X}(\mathbold{y},\mathbold{z}_{k})\right\rVert\leq\chi({N_{\mathrm{e}}})\left\lVert\mathbold{x}-\mathbold{y}\right\rVert,\quad\forall\mathbold{x},\mathbold{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}.

The convergence under Assumption 2 is thus another consequence of Lemma 4. ∎

Remark 3 (Exact convergence).

Notice that when exact local solvers are employed (hence ν=0𝜈0\nu=0 in Assumption 2) then Propositions 2 and 3 prove exact convergence to the fixed point [\mathbold​x¯⊤​\mathbold​z¯⊤]⊤superscriptdelimited-[]superscript¯\mathbold𝑥topsuperscript¯\mathbold𝑧toptop[\bar{\mathbold{x}}^{\top}\ \bar{\mathbold{z}}^{\top}]^{\top}, even in the presence of partial participation. As a consequence, the proposed algorithm indeed allows for the use of local training without degrading accuracy (objective (i) in section III-B).

VI Privacy Analysis

In this section, we prove that Algorithm 1, utilizing the noisy gradient descent eq. 13 as local training method, guarantees RDP for every data sample in 𝒟:=∪i=1N𝒟iassign𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}:=\cup_{i=1}^{N}\mathcal{D}_{i}. We will derive this result in the case of full agents’ participation, which can provide an upper bound to the privacy guarantee with partial participation. Before proceeding to the analysis, we make the following assumption.

Assumption 3 (Sensitivity).

For each i∈{1,…,N}𝑖1…𝑁i\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, there exists some L>0𝐿0L>0 such that

∥∇fi𝒟i​(x)−∇fi𝒟i′​(x)∥≤Lq,∀x∈ℝnformulae-sequencedelimited-∥∥∇superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖𝑥∇superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑖𝑥𝐿𝑞for-all𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛\left\lVert\nabla f_{i}^{\mathcal{D}_{i}}(x)-\nabla f_{i}^{\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{i}}(x)\right\rVert\leq\frac{L}{q},\quad\forall x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}

where ∇fi𝒟i∇superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖\nabla f_{i}^{\mathcal{D}_{i}} denotes the gradient of fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} induced by the dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, and 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} and 𝒟i′subscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑖\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{i} are neighboring datasets of size q𝑞q.

Assumption 3 quantifies the sensitivity of local gradient queries, which is a well-established concept in the field of machine learning with differential privacy [20, 42]. It is commonly satisfied in various learning problems, such as those involving l2subscript𝑙2l_{2} regularized logistic loss (where the regularization ensures that Assumption 1 is also satisfied). For more general loss functions, the use of clipped gradients during training guarantees that Assumption 3 is verified [46]. Specifically, the gradients are clipped using the expression ∇ℓi​(xi;ξi(j))⋅min⁡{1,L2​∥∇ℓi​(xi;ξi(j))∥}⋅∇subscriptℓ𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑗1𝐿2delimited-∥∥∇subscriptℓ𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑗\nabla\ell_{i}(x_{i};\xi_{i}^{(j)})\cdot\min\left\{1,\frac{L}{2\lVert\nabla\ell_{i}(x_{i};\xi_{i}^{(j)})\rVert}\right\}, where ξi(j)∈𝒟isuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑗subscript𝒟𝑖\xi_{i}^{(j)}\in\mathcal{D}_{i}.

We are now ready to provide our privacy guarantee.

Proposition 4 (Privacy).

Suppose Assumptions 1 and 3 hold. Let the agents employ the noisy gradient descent eq. 13 with noise variance τ2<∞superscript𝜏2\tau^{2}<\infty as local solver. If the step-size γ<2/(λ¯+ρ−1)𝛾2¯𝜆superscript𝜌1\gamma<2/({\bar{\lambda}}+\rho^{-1}) and each xi,0subscript𝑥𝑖0x_{i,0} is drawn from 𝒩​(0,2​τ2​In/λ¯)𝒩02superscript𝜏2subscript𝐼𝑛¯𝜆\mathcal{N}(0,2\tau^{2}I_{n}/{\underline{\lambda}}), then Algorithm 1 satisfies (λ,ε)𝜆𝜀(\lambda,\varepsilon)-Rényi differential privacy with

ε≤λ​L2λ¯​τ2​q2​(1−e−λ¯​γ​K​Ne/2)𝜀𝜆superscript𝐿2¯𝜆superscript𝜏2superscript𝑞21superscript𝑒¯𝜆𝛾𝐾subscript𝑁e2\varepsilon\leq\frac{\lambda L^{2}}{{\underline{\lambda}}\tau^{2}q^{2}}\left(1-e^{-{\underline{\lambda}}\gamma K{N_{\mathrm{e}}}/2}\right)

where q𝑞q is the number of local samples, λ¯¯𝜆{\underline{\lambda}} and λ¯¯𝜆{\bar{\lambda}} are the strong convexity modulus and smoothness parameter of the local cost, respectively.

Proof.

We denote by \mathbold​xk:=[x1,k⊤,…,xN,k⊤]⊤assign\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑥top1𝑘…subscriptsuperscript𝑥top𝑁𝑘top{\mathbold{x}}_{k}:=[{x}^{\top}_{1,k},\ldots,{x}^{\top}_{N,k}]^{\top} and \mathbold​xk′:=[x1,k′⁣⊤,…,xN,k′⁣⊤]⊤assign\mathboldsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘′superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑥′top1𝑘…subscriptsuperscript𝑥′top𝑁𝑘top{\mathbold{x}}_{k}^{\prime}:=[{x}^{\prime\top}_{1,k},\ldots,{x}^{\prime\top}_{N,k}]^{\top} the iterates produced by all the agents at the k𝑘k’s iteration based on the neighboring datasets 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime}, respectively. Furthermore, let 𝑿ksubscript𝑿𝑘\bm{X}_{k} and 𝑿k′subscriptsuperscript𝑿′𝑘\bm{X}^{\prime}_{k} be the corresponding random variables that model \mathbold​xk\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘{\mathbold{x}}_{k} and \mathbold​xk′\mathboldsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘′{\mathbold{x}}_{k}^{\prime}. We abuse the notation to also denote their probability distributions by 𝑿ksubscript𝑿𝑘\bm{X}_{k} and 𝑿k′subscriptsuperscript𝑿′𝑘\bm{X}^{\prime}_{k}. We are interested in the worst-case Rényi divergence between the output distributions based on 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime}, i.e., Dλ(𝑿K||𝑿K′){\rm D}_{\lambda}(\bm{X}_{K}||\bm{X}^{\prime}_{K}). Since each agent generates the Gaussian noise independently, xi,ksubscript𝑥𝑖𝑘x_{i,k} is independent between different i𝑖i. In addition, two neighboring datasets 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime} only have at most one data point that is different. Without loss of generality, we assume this different data point is possessed by agent i𝑖i. Then, we obtain from [47, Theorem 27] that

Dλ(𝑿K||𝑿K′)=Dλ(𝑿i,K||𝑿i,K′).{\rm D}_{\lambda}(\bm{X}_{K}||\bm{X}^{\prime}_{K})={\rm D}_{\lambda}(\bm{X}_{i,K}||\bm{X}^{\prime}_{i,K}).

Next, we follow the approach in [20] to quantify the privacy loss during the local training process at the k𝑘k’s iteration, that is, Dλ(𝑿i,k+1||𝑿i,k+1′)−Dλ(𝑿i,k||𝑿i,k′){\rm D}_{\lambda}(\bm{X}_{i,k+1}||\bm{X}^{\prime}_{i,k+1})-{\rm D}_{\lambda}(\bm{X}_{i,k}||\bm{X}^{\prime}_{i,k}). Recall that the local training update at the ℓℓ\ell-th step reads

wi,kℓ+1=wi,kℓ−γ​∇di,k​(wi,kℓ)+ti,kℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓ1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓ𝛾∇subscript𝑑𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑘ℓ\begin{split}&w_{i,k}^{\ell+1}=w_{i,k}^{\ell}-\gamma\nabla d_{i,k}(w_{i,k}^{\ell})+t_{i,k}^{\ell}\end{split} (19)

where wi,k0=xi,ksuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘0subscript𝑥𝑖𝑘w_{i,k}^{0}=x_{i,k} and ti,kℓ∼2​γ​𝒩​(0,τ2​In)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑘ℓ2𝛾𝒩0superscript𝜏2subscript𝐼𝑛t_{i,k}^{\ell}\sim\sqrt{2\gamma}\mathcal{N}(0,\tau^{2}{I}_{n}). Note that di,ksubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘d_{i,k} is (λ¯+ρ−1)¯𝜆superscript𝜌1({\underline{\lambda}}+\rho^{-1})-strongly convex and (λ¯+ρ−1)¯𝜆superscript𝜌1({\bar{\lambda}}+\rho^{-1})-smooth. Let 𝑾i,kγ​ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑖𝑘𝛾ℓ\bm{W}_{i,k}^{\gamma\ell} and 𝑾i,k′⁣γ​ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑖𝑘′𝛾ℓ\bm{W}_{i,k}^{\prime\gamma\ell} be the probability distributions that model wi,kℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓw_{i,k}^{\ell} and wi,k′⁣ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘′ℓw_{i,k}^{\prime\ell}. During the time interval γ​ℓ<t<γ​(ℓ+1)𝛾ℓ𝑡𝛾ℓ1\gamma\ell<t<\gamma(\ell+1), the updates in eq. 19 on the datasets 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D^{\prime}} are modeled using the following stochastic processes.

{𝑾i,kt=𝑾i,kγ​ℓ−γ​U1​(𝑾i,kγ​ℓ)−(t−γ​ℓ)​U2​(𝑾i,kγ​ℓ)+2​(t−γ​ℓ)​τ2​𝑮ℓ𝑾i,k′⁣t=𝑾i,k′⁣γ​ℓ−γ​U1​(𝑾i,k′⁣γ​ℓ)+(t−γ​ℓ)​U2​(𝑾i,k′⁣γ​ℓ)+2​(t−γ​ℓ)​τ2​𝑮ℓ\left\{\begin{aligned} \bm{W}_{i,k}^{t}&=\bm{W}_{i,k}^{\gamma\ell}-\gamma U_{1}(\bm{W}_{i,k}^{\gamma\ell})-(t-\gamma\ell)U_{2}(\bm{W}_{i,k}^{\gamma\ell})\\ &\quad+\sqrt{2(t-\gamma\ell)\tau^{2}}\bm{G}^{\ell}\\ \bm{W}_{i,k}^{\prime t}&=\bm{W}_{i,k}^{\prime\gamma\ell}-\gamma U_{1}(\bm{W}_{i,k}^{\prime\gamma\ell})+(t-\gamma\ell)U_{2}(\bm{W}_{i,k}^{\prime\gamma\ell})\\ &\quad+\sqrt{2(t-\gamma\ell)\tau^{2}}\bm{G}^{\ell}\end{aligned}\right. where 𝑮ℓ∼𝒩​(0,In)similar-tosuperscript𝑮ℓ𝒩0subscript𝐼𝑛\bm{G}^{\ell}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,{I}_{n}), U1​(wi,k)=(∇di,k𝒟​(wi,k)+∇di,k𝒟′​(wi,k))/2subscript𝑈1subscript𝑤𝑖𝑘∇superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘𝒟subscript𝑤𝑖𝑘∇superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘superscript𝒟′subscript𝑤𝑖𝑘2U_{1}(w_{i,k})=(\nabla d_{i,k}^{\mathcal{D}}(w_{i,k})+\nabla d_{i,k}^{\mathcal{D}^{\prime}}(w_{i,k}))/2 and U2​(wi,k)=(∇di,k𝒟​(wi,k)−∇di,k𝒟′​(wi,k))/2subscript𝑈2subscript𝑤𝑖𝑘∇superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘𝒟subscript𝑤𝑖𝑘∇superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘superscript𝒟′subscript𝑤𝑖𝑘2U_{2}(w_{i,k})=(\nabla d_{i,k}^{\mathcal{D}}(w_{i,k})-\nabla d_{i,k}^{\mathcal{D}^{\prime}}(w_{i,k}))/2. d​𝑾i,kt=−U2​(wi,kℓ)​d​t+2​τ2​d​𝒁td​𝑾i,k′⁣t=−U2​(wi,k′⁣ℓ)​d​t+2​τ2​d​𝒁t𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑾𝑖𝑘𝑡subscript𝑈2superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘ℓ𝑑𝑡2superscript𝜏2𝑑superscript𝒁𝑡𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑾𝑖𝑘′𝑡subscript𝑈2superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘′ℓ𝑑𝑡2superscript𝜏2𝑑superscript𝒁𝑡\begin{split}d\bm{W}_{i,k}^{t}&=-U_{2}(w_{i,k}^{\ell})dt+\sqrt{2\tau^{2}}d\bm{Z}^{t}\\ d\bm{W}_{i,k}^{\prime t}&=-U_{2}(w_{i,k}^{\prime\ell})dt+\sqrt{2\tau^{2}}d\bm{Z}^{t}\end{split}

where d​𝒁t∼d​t​𝒩​(0,In)similar-to𝑑superscript𝒁𝑡𝑑𝑡𝒩0subscript𝐼𝑛d\bm{Z}^{t}\sim\sqrt{dt}\mathcal{N}(0,I_{n}) describes the Wiener process.

For the training process at k𝑘k’s iteration, we use Assumption 3 and a similar argument with (67) in [20, Theorem 2] to obtain

Dλ(𝑾i,kNe||𝑾i,k′⁣Ne)λ−L2λ¯​τ2​q2≤(Dλk(𝑾i,k0||𝑾i,k′⁣0)λk−L2λ¯​τ2​q2)​e−λ¯​γ​Ne/2\begin{split}&\frac{{\rm D}_{\lambda}(\bm{W}^{{N_{\mathrm{e}}}}_{i,k}||\bm{W}^{\prime{N_{\mathrm{e}}}}_{i,k})}{\lambda}-\frac{L^{2}}{{\underline{\lambda}}\tau^{2}q^{2}}\\ &\leq\left(\frac{{\rm D}_{\lambda_{k}}(\bm{W}^{0}_{i,k}||\bm{W}^{\prime 0}_{i,k})}{\lambda_{k}}-\frac{L^{2}}{{\underline{\lambda}}\tau^{2}q^{2}}\right)e^{-{\underline{\lambda}}\gamma{N_{\mathrm{e}}}/2}\end{split}

for some λk>1subscript𝜆𝑘1\lambda_{k}>1. Because of lines 5 and 9 in Algorithm 1, there holds Dλk(𝑾i,k0||𝑾i,k′⁣0)=Dλk(𝑿i,k||𝑿i,k′){\rm D}_{\lambda_{k}}(\bm{W}_{i,k}^{0}||\bm{W}_{i,k}^{\prime 0})={\rm D}_{\lambda_{k}}(\bm{X}_{i,k}||\bm{X}^{\prime}_{i,k}) and Dλ(𝑾i,kNe||𝑾i,k′⁣Ne)=Dλ(𝑿i,k+1||𝑿i,k+1′){\rm D}_{\lambda}(\bm{W}_{i,k}^{{N_{\mathrm{e}}}}||\bm{W}_{i,k}^{\prime{N_{\mathrm{e}}}})={\rm D}_{\lambda}(\bm{X}_{i,k+1}||\bm{X}^{\prime}_{i,k+1}). By iterating over k=0,…,K−1𝑘0…𝐾1k=0,\dots,K-1, we obtain

Dλ(𝑿i,K||𝑿i,K′)λ−L2λ¯​τ2​q2≤(Dλ0(𝑿i,0||𝑿i,0′)λ0−L2λ¯​τ2​q2)​e−λ¯​γ​K​Ne/2\begin{split}&\frac{{\rm D}_{\lambda}(\bm{X}_{i,K}||\bm{X}^{\prime}_{i,K})}{\lambda}-\frac{L^{2}}{{\underline{\lambda}}\tau^{2}q^{2}}\\ &\leq\left(\frac{{\rm D}_{\lambda_{0}}(\bm{X}_{i,0}||\bm{X}^{\prime}_{i,0})}{\lambda_{0}}-\frac{L^{2}}{{\underline{\lambda}}\tau^{2}q^{2}}\right)e^{-{\underline{\lambda}}\gamma K{N_{\mathrm{e}}}/2}\end{split}

for some λ0subscript𝜆0\lambda_{0}. Recall that xi,0=xi,0′subscript𝑥𝑖0subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑖0x_{i,0}=x^{\prime}_{i,0}, we arrive at

Dλ(𝑿i,K||𝑿i,K′)=Dλ(𝑿i,K||𝑿i,K′)≤λ​L2λ¯​τ2​q2​(1−e−λ¯​γ​K​Ne/2).\begin{split}&{\rm D}_{\lambda}(\bm{X}_{i,K}||\bm{X}^{\prime}_{i,K})={\rm D}_{\lambda}(\bm{X}_{i,K}||\bm{X}^{\prime}_{i,K})\\ &\leq\frac{\lambda L^{2}}{{\underline{\lambda}}\tau^{2}q^{2}}\left(1-e^{-{\underline{\lambda}}\gamma K{N_{\mathrm{e}}}/2}\right).\end{split}

∎

By applying Lemma 5, we can convert the RDP guarantee presented in Proposition 4 into an (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-ADP guarantee, where ε𝜀\varepsilon is given by the following expression:

ε=λ​L2λ¯​τ2​q2​(1−e−λ¯​γ​K​Ne/2)+log⁡(1/δ)λ−1,∀δ∈(0,1).formulae-sequence𝜀𝜆superscript𝐿2¯𝜆superscript𝜏2superscript𝑞21superscript𝑒¯𝜆𝛾𝐾subscript𝑁e21𝛿𝜆1for-all𝛿01\varepsilon=\frac{\lambda L^{2}}{{\underline{\lambda}}\tau^{2}q^{2}}\left(1-e^{-{\underline{\lambda}}\gamma K{N_{\mathrm{e}}}/2}\right)+\frac{\log(1/\delta)}{\lambda-1},\quad\forall\delta\in(0,1).

This result reveals that the privacy loss of Algorithm 1 grows as the number of iterations increases, eventually reaching a constant upper bound. This characterization is based on the dynamics analysis of RDP loss in [20], and is arguably tighter than previous approaches based on advanced composition of differential privacy [48], privacy amplification by iteration [49], and privacy amplification by subsampling [12, 40] (cf. the discussion in [20]).

The use of noisy gradient descent as a privacy preserving mechanism of course has an impact on the accuracy of Algorithm 1. The following result quantifies the inexact convergence of the algorithm for a given privacy threshold.

Corollary 1 (Accuracy).

Consider Algorithm 1 with noisy gradient descent eq. 13 as local training method, with noise variance τ2<∞superscript𝜏2\tau^{2}<\infty and step-size γ<2/(λ¯+ρ−1)𝛾2¯𝜆superscript𝜌1\gamma<2/({\bar{\lambda}}+\rho^{-1}). Suppose that each xi,0subscript𝑥𝑖0x_{i,0} is drawn from 𝒩​(0,2​τ2​In/λ¯)𝒩02superscript𝜏2subscript𝐼𝑛¯𝜆\mathcal{N}(0,2\tau^{2}I_{n}/{\underline{\lambda}}), and that Assumptions 1 and 2 hold. Then at time K∈ℕ𝐾ℕK\in\mathbb{N} we have

𝔼​[∥[\mathbold​xK−\mathbold​x¯\mathbold​zK−\mathbold​z¯]∥]𝔼delimited-[]delimited-∥∥matrix\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝐾¯\mathbold𝑥\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝐾¯\mathbold𝑧\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\begin{bmatrix}\mathbold{x}_{K}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\\ \mathbold{z}_{K}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\end{bmatrix}\right\rVert\right] ≤∥S∥K​∥[\mathbold​x0−\mathbold​x¯\mathbold​z0−\mathbold​z¯]∥+absentlimit-fromsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑆𝐾delimited-∥∥matrix\mathboldsubscript𝑥0¯\mathbold𝑥\mathboldsubscript𝑧0¯\mathbold𝑧\displaystyle\leq\left\lVert S\right\rVert^{K}\left\lVert\begin{bmatrix}\mathbold{x}_{0}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\\ \mathbold{z}_{0}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\end{bmatrix}\right\rVert+
+1−∥S∥K1−∥S∥​τ​10​n​N​γ​1−χNe1−χ1superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑆𝐾1delimited-∥∥𝑆𝜏10𝑛𝑁𝛾1superscript𝜒subscript𝑁e1𝜒\displaystyle+\frac{1-\left\lVert S\right\rVert^{K}}{1-\left\lVert S\right\rVert}\tau\sqrt{10nN\gamma}\frac{1-\chi^{N_{\mathrm{e}}}}{1-\chi}

Proof.

The result follows as a consequence of Proposition 2 by showing that Algorithm 1 with noisy gradient descent as local training method can be written as eq. 18. Denote by 𝒳​(\mathbold​xk,\mathbold​zk)𝒳\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘\mathcal{X}(\mathbold{x}_{k},\mathbold{z}_{k}) and 𝒳^​(\mathbold​xk,\mathbold​zk)^𝒳\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝑘\hat{\mathcal{X}}(\mathbold{x}_{k},\mathbold{z}_{k}) the output of the local training step when gradient, respectively noisy gradient, is used. We have therefore the following chain of inequalities

where (i) holds by triangle inequality, (ii) by contractiveness of 𝒢ksubscript𝒢𝑘\mathcal{G}_{k}, and (iii) by iterating (i) and (ii), and using \mathbold​wk0=\mathbold​w^k0=\mathbold​xk\mathboldsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘0superscriptsubscript^\mathbold𝑤𝑘0\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝑘\mathbold{w}_{k}^{0}=\hat{\mathbold{w}}_{k}^{0}=\mathbold{x}_{k}.
