𝔼​[∥\mathbold​ek∥]≤5​τ​2​n​N​γ​1−χNe1−χ.𝔼delimited-[]delimited-∥∥\mathboldsubscript𝑒𝑘5𝜏2𝑛𝑁𝛾1superscript𝜒subscript𝑁e1𝜒\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\mathbold{e}_{k}\right\rVert\right]\leq\sqrt{5}\tau\sqrt{2nN\gamma}\frac{1-\chi^{N_{\mathrm{e}}}}{1-\chi}.

Therefore, applying Proposition 2 the thesis follows. ∎

To summarize, injecting noise drawn from 2​γ​𝒩​(0,τ2​\mathbold​In​N)2𝛾𝒩0superscript𝜏2\mathboldsubscript𝐼𝑛𝑁\sqrt{2\gamma}\mathcal{N}(0,\tau^{2}\mathbold{I}_{nN}) guarantees that Algorithm 1 is (λ,ε)𝜆𝜀(\lambda,\varepsilon)-Rényi differentially privacy with

ε≤λ​L2λ¯​τ2​q2​(1−e−λ¯​γ​K​Ne/2)𝜀𝜆superscript𝐿2¯𝜆superscript𝜏2superscript𝑞21superscript𝑒¯𝜆𝛾𝐾subscript𝑁e2\varepsilon\leq\frac{\lambda L^{2}}{{\underline{\lambda}}\tau^{2}q^{2}}\left(1-e^{-{\underline{\lambda}}\gamma K{N_{\mathrm{e}}}/2}\right)

and the accuracy is upper bounded by

𝔼​[∥[\mathbold​xK−\mathbold​x¯\mathbold​zK−\mathbold​z¯]∥]𝔼delimited-[]delimited-∥∥matrix\mathboldsubscript𝑥𝐾¯\mathbold𝑥\mathboldsubscript𝑧𝐾¯\mathbold𝑧\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\begin{bmatrix}\mathbold{x}_{K}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\\ \mathbold{z}_{K}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\end{bmatrix}\right\rVert\right] ≤∥S∥K​∥[\mathbold​x0−\mathbold​x¯\mathbold​z0−\mathbold​z¯]∥+absentlimit-fromsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑆𝐾delimited-∥∥matrix\mathboldsubscript𝑥0¯\mathbold𝑥\mathboldsubscript𝑧0¯\mathbold𝑧\displaystyle\leq\left\lVert S\right\rVert^{K}\left\lVert\begin{bmatrix}\mathbold{x}_{0}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\\ \mathbold{z}_{0}-\bar{\mathbold{z}}\end{bmatrix}\right\rVert+
+1−∥S∥K1−∥S∥​τ​10​n​N​γ​1−χNe1−χ.1superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑆𝐾1delimited-∥∥𝑆𝜏10𝑛𝑁𝛾1superscript𝜒subscript𝑁e1𝜒\displaystyle+\frac{1-\left\lVert S\right\rVert^{K}}{1-\left\lVert S\right\rVert}\tau\sqrt{10nN\gamma}\frac{1-\chi^{N_{\mathrm{e}}}}{1-\chi}.

Therefore, the larger the noise variance τ2superscript𝜏2\tau^{2} is, the less accurate the algorithm becomes. This captures the well-known trade-off between guaranteeing privacy and achieving accuracy [10, 21].

VII Numerical Results

In this section we evaluate the performance of the proposed Fed-PLT, and compare it with the alternative algorithms discussed in section I-A. We consider a logistic regression problem characterized by the local loss functions

fi​(x)=1mi​∑h=1milog⁡(1+exp⁡(−bi,h​ai,h​x))+ϵ2​N​∥x∥2subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥1subscript𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ1subscript𝑚𝑖1subscript𝑏𝑖ℎsubscript𝑎𝑖ℎ𝑥italic-ϵ2𝑁superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥2f_{i}(x)=\frac{1}{m_{i}}\sum_{h=1}^{m_{i}}\log\left(1+\exp\left(-b_{i,h}a_{i,h}x\right)\right)+\frac{\epsilon}{2N}\left\lVert x\right\rVert^{2}

where ai,h∈ℝ1×nsubscript𝑎𝑖ℎsuperscriptℝ1𝑛a_{i,h}\in\mathbb{R}^{1\times n} and bi,h∈{−1,1}subscript𝑏𝑖ℎ11b_{i,h}\in\{-1,1\}. In particular, we have n=16𝑛16n=16 (151515 features plus the intercept), mi=20subscript𝑚𝑖20m_{i}=20, and ϵ=5italic-ϵ5\epsilon=5. The local data points {(ai,h,bi,h)}h=1misuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖ℎsubscript𝑏𝑖ℎℎ1subscript𝑚𝑖\{(a_{i,h},b_{i,h})\}_{h=1}^{m_{i}} are randomly generated, to have a roughly 50−50505050-50 split between the two classes. The local costs are strongly convex and smooth, in particular fi∈ℱϵ,qi/4+ϵ​(ℝn)subscript𝑓𝑖subscriptℱitalic-ϵsubscript𝑞𝑖4italic-ϵsuperscriptℝ𝑛f_{i}\in\mathcal{F}_{\epsilon,q_{i}/4+\epsilon}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right), qi=maxh=1,…,mi∥ai,h∥2q_{i}=\max_{h=1,\ldots,m_{i}}\left\lVert a_{i,h}\right\rVert^{2}. The simulations are implemented in Python building on top of the tvopt library [51]. All the results involving randomness are averaged over 100100100 Monte Carlo iterations.

VII-A Comparison with different solvers and partial participation

We start by comparing the proposed Fed-PLT with the alternative algorithms discussed in section I-A: Fed-PD [29], FedLin [30], TAMUNA [31], LED [32], and 5GCS [14]. For all algorithms except TAMUNA [31], we set the number of local training epochs to Ne=10subscript𝑁e10{N_{\mathrm{e}}}=10; for TAMUNA, the number of local epochs at time k𝑘k is drawn from a random geometric distribution with mean equals to Nesubscript𝑁e{N_{\mathrm{e}}}. The other parameters of the algorithms (e.g. step-size of the local solvers) are tuned to achieve the best performance possible.

In Table II we compare the algorithms in terms of convergence rate when using two different local solvers, gradient descent and accelerated gradient descent. Notice that, except for Fed-PLT and 5GCS, no convergence guarantee is provided when the accelerated gradient is used. Additionally, for the algorithms that allow it, we also compare the performance with full participation (all agents are active at all time k𝑘k) and with partial participation (only N/2𝑁2N/2 agents are active). In the case of partial participation, the active agents are selected uniformly at random.

As we can see from Table II, Fed-PLT achieves the best convergence rate in all scenarios. Notice that Fed-PD, FedLin, TAMUNA, LED are not designed to use accelerated gradient, but a straightforward modification allows for it. And interestingly, they do achieve convergence, even though there are no theoretical guarantees of it. Another observation is that the convergence rate increases when partial participation is applied. This is in line with previous results on decentralized optimization [52]. Finally, it is interesting to notice that the use of gradient descent as local solver yields often lower convergence rates than accelerated gradient descent. A possible explanation is that the overall convergence is not dominated by the convergence rate of the local solver. For example in the case of Fed-PLT, the convergence may be dominated by ζ𝜁\zeta, the convergence rate of the exact PRS (cf. Proposition 1).

We further analyze the performance of Fed-PLT with partial participation. In Table III we report the empirical convergence rate computed for different numbers of participating agents, up to full participation of the N𝑁N agents. As observed above, the fewer agents participate at each iteration, the higher the convergence rate.

We conclude this section by studying the performance of Fed-PLT when the privacy-preserving noisy gradient descent is used as a local solver. As discussed in section VI, the use of such solver results in a decrease in accuracy of the learned model, with the asymptotic error being bounded by a non-zero value (cf. Corollary 1). In Table IV we report the empirical value of such asymptotic error when different values of the noise variance τ𝜏\tau are used. As foreseen by Corollary 1, the larger the variance is the larger the asymptotic error.

VII-B Tuning the parameters of Fed-PLT

The results of the previous section were obtained by setting Ne=10subscript𝑁e10{N_{\mathrm{e}}}=10 in Fed-PLT, and tuning its parameter ρ𝜌\rho to achieve an optimal convergence rate. In this section we further characterize the effect of both ρ𝜌\rho and Nesubscript𝑁e{N_{\mathrm{e}}} on Fed-PLT’s convergence.

We start by showing in Figure 2 the empirical convergence rate when Ne=10subscript𝑁e10{N_{\mathrm{e}}}=10 and ρ𝜌\rho ranges between 10−3superscript10310^{-3} and 103superscript10310^{3}. As we can see, the rate is optimized for a value of ρ≈0.3𝜌0.3\rho\approx 0.3 and grows larger for extreme values in both directions. The rate thus resembles that of the exact PRS from which Fed-PLT is derived, see e.g. [53, Figures 1, 2].

In Figure 3 we plot the rate obtained setting ρ=0.3𝜌0.3\rho=0.3 and varying the number of local epochs Nesubscript𝑁e{N_{\mathrm{e}}} from 111 to 505050. Interestingly, the rate is not a monotonically decreasing function of Nesubscript𝑁e{N_{\mathrm{e}}}. Rather, the rate decreases to a minimum for Ne≈10subscript𝑁e10{N_{\mathrm{e}}}\approx 10, and then increases again, settling on a constant value for Ne>20subscript𝑁e20{N_{\mathrm{e}}}>20. Further simulations show that such rate is constant for all values Ne>20subscript𝑁e20{N_{\mathrm{e}}}>20 and very close to the rate ζ𝜁\zeta of the exact PRS (where Ne→∞→subscript𝑁e{N_{\mathrm{e}}}\to\infty). Therefore, it appears that the use of an inexact proximal computation during local training can improve the speed of convergence. Quantifying this speed-up from a theoretical perspective is an interesting direction for future research.

We conclude by remarking that these results lend further credence to the fact that the convergence rate of Fed-PLT is dominated by ζ𝜁\zeta rather than by the local training solver. Indeed, as observed Figure 2 resembles the rate of the exact PRS, and in Figure 3 the rate is very close to ζ𝜁\zeta even for small values of Ne≈20subscript𝑁e20{N_{\mathrm{e}}}\approx 20.

Lemma 7 (Contraction of accelerated gradient).

Let f∈ℱλ¯,λ¯​(ℝn)𝑓subscriptℱ¯𝜆¯𝜆superscriptℝ𝑛f\in\mathcal{F}_{{\underline{\lambda}},{\bar{\lambda}}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right), then the accelerated gradient descent

\mathbold​xℓ+1\mathboldsuperscript𝑥ℓ1\displaystyle\mathbold{x}^{\ell+1} =\mathbold​wℓ−1λ¯​∇f​(\mathbold​wℓ)absent\mathboldsuperscript𝑤ℓ1¯𝜆∇𝑓\mathboldsuperscript𝑤ℓ\displaystyle=\mathbold{w}^{\ell}-\frac{1}{{\bar{\lambda}}}\nabla f(\mathbold{w}^{\ell})
\mathbold​wℓ+1\mathboldsuperscript𝑤ℓ1\displaystyle\mathbold{w}^{\ell+1} =\mathbold​xℓ+1+λ¯−λ¯λ¯+λ¯​(\mathbold​xℓ+1−\mathbold​xℓ)absent\mathboldsuperscript𝑥ℓ1¯𝜆¯𝜆¯𝜆¯𝜆\mathboldsuperscript𝑥ℓ1\mathboldsuperscript𝑥ℓ\displaystyle=\mathbold{x}^{\ell+1}+\frac{\sqrt{{\bar{\lambda}}}-\sqrt{{\underline{\lambda}}}}{\sqrt{{\bar{\lambda}}}+\sqrt{{\underline{\lambda}}}}(\mathbold{x}^{\ell+1}-\mathbold{x}^{\ell})

with initial conditions \mathbold​x0=\mathbold​w0\mathboldsuperscript𝑥0\mathboldsuperscript𝑤0\mathbold{x}^{0}=\mathbold{w}^{0} is such that

∥\mathbold​xℓ−\mathbold​x¯∥≤(1+λ¯/λ¯)​(1−λ¯/λ¯)ℓ​∥\mathbold​x0−\mathbold​x¯∥delimited-∥∥\mathboldsuperscript𝑥ℓ¯\mathbold𝑥1¯𝜆¯𝜆superscript1¯𝜆¯𝜆ℓdelimited-∥∥\mathboldsuperscript𝑥0¯\mathbold𝑥\left\lVert\mathbold{x}^{\ell}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert\leq\left(1+{\bar{\lambda}}/{\underline{\lambda}}\right)\left(1-\sqrt{{\underline{\lambda}}/{\bar{\lambda}}}\right)^{\ell}\left\lVert\mathbold{x}^{0}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert

where \mathbold​x¯¯\mathbold𝑥\bar{\mathbold{x}} is the unique minimum of f𝑓f. Therefore,

ℓ>log⁡(1+λ¯/λ¯)|log⁡(1−λ¯/λ¯)|ℓ1¯𝜆¯𝜆1¯𝜆¯𝜆\ell>\frac{\log(1+{\bar{\lambda}}/{\underline{\lambda}})}{|\log(1-\sqrt{{\underline{\lambda}}/{\bar{\lambda}}})|}

is a sufficient condition for the accelerated gradient to be contractive.

Proof.

Define ϕℓ=f​(\mathbold​xℓ)−f​(\mathbold​x¯)+λ¯2​∥\mathbold​wℓ−\mathbold​x¯∥2,superscriptitalic-ϕℓ𝑓\mathboldsuperscript𝑥ℓ𝑓¯\mathbold𝑥¯𝜆2superscriptdelimited-∥∥\mathboldsuperscript𝑤ℓ¯\mathbold𝑥2\phi^{\ell}=f(\mathbold{x}^{\ell})-f(\bar{\mathbold{x}})+\frac{{\underline{\lambda}}}{2}\left\lVert\mathbold{w}^{\ell}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert^{2}, then by [41, Theorem 4.14] we have that ϕℓ+1≤ζ​ϕℓsuperscriptitalic-ϕℓ1𝜁superscriptitalic-ϕℓ\phi^{\ell+1}\leq\zeta\phi^{\ell} with ζ=1−λ¯/λ¯𝜁1¯𝜆¯𝜆\zeta=1-\sqrt{{\underline{\lambda}}/{\bar{\lambda}}}. Now, by smoothness of f𝑓f and the fact that ∇f​(\mathbold​x¯)∇𝑓¯\mathbold𝑥\nabla f(\bar{\mathbold{x}}) we have f​(\mathbold​x0)−f​(\mathbold​x¯)≤(λ¯/2)​∥\mathbold​x0−\mathbold​x¯∥2𝑓\mathboldsuperscript𝑥0𝑓¯\mathbold𝑥¯𝜆2superscriptdelimited-∥∥\mathboldsuperscript𝑥0¯\mathbold𝑥2f(\mathbold{x}^{0})-f(\bar{\mathbold{x}})\leq({\bar{\lambda}}/2)\left\lVert\mathbold{x}^{0}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert^{2}, which implies

ϕ0≤λ¯+λ¯2​∥\mathbold​w0−\mathbold​x¯∥2.superscriptitalic-ϕ0¯𝜆¯𝜆2superscriptdelimited-∥∥\mathboldsuperscript𝑤0¯\mathbold𝑥2\phi^{0}\leq\frac{{\bar{\lambda}}+{\underline{\lambda}}}{2}\left\lVert\mathbold{w}^{0}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert^{2}.

Therefore, using ϕℓ+1≤ζ​ϕℓsuperscriptitalic-ϕℓ1𝜁superscriptitalic-ϕℓ\phi^{\ell+1}\leq\zeta\phi^{\ell} recursively we get

ϕℓ≤ζℓ​ϕ0≤λ¯+λ¯2​∥\mathbold​w0−\mathbold​x¯∥2superscriptitalic-ϕℓsuperscript𝜁ℓsuperscriptitalic-ϕ0¯𝜆¯𝜆2superscriptdelimited-∥∥\mathboldsuperscript𝑤0¯\mathbold𝑥2\phi^{\ell}\leq\zeta^{\ell}\phi^{0}\leq\frac{{\bar{\lambda}}+{\underline{\lambda}}}{2}\left\lVert\mathbold{w}^{0}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert^{2}

and, together with the fact (λ¯/2)​∥\mathbold​wℓ−\mathbold​x¯∥2≤ϕℓ¯𝜆2superscriptdelimited-∥∥\mathboldsuperscript𝑤ℓ¯\mathbold𝑥2superscriptitalic-ϕℓ({\underline{\lambda}}/2)\left\lVert\mathbold{w}^{\ell}-\bar{\mathbold{x}}\right\rVert^{2}\leq\phi^{\ell} (which holds by definition of ϕℓsuperscriptitalic-ϕℓ\phi^{\ell}), the thesis follows. The algorithm is then contractive w.r.t. \mathbold​x\mathbold𝑥\mathbold{x} whenever a suitably large ℓℓ\ell is chosen. ∎
